revisions.rev: {{about|the annual [[American football]] game between [[Virginia Cavaliers|Virginia]] and [[Virginia Tech Hokies|Virginia Tech]]|other trophies|Commonwealth Cup (disambiguation)}} {| class="infobox" style="width: 28em; font-size: 95%;" |- | colspan="2" style="text-align: center; font-size: 150%;" | '''Commonwealth Cup''' |- | style="text-align:center; width:13em;"| [[File:Virginia Cavaliers text logo.svg|90px|Virginia logo]] | style="text-align:center; vertical-align:middle; width:13em;"|[[File:VT logo.svg|155px|Virginia Tech logo]] |- {{#if: {{{image location|}}} | {{!}} style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" {{!}} }} |- | style="text-align:center;"| '''[[Virginia Cavaliers football|Virginia Cavaliers]]''' | style="text-align:center;"| '''[[Virginia Tech Hokies football|Virginia Tech Hokies]]''' |- | '''Originated''' | 1895 |- | '''Most recent''' | 2011 |- | '''Next match''' | 2012 |- | '''Continuity''' | 41 years |- | '''Rivalry Series''' | Virginia Tech leads, 51-37-5 |- | '''Last Winner''' | Virginia Tech (2011) |- |} The '''Commonwealth Cup''' is an American [[college football]] [[College rivalry#ACC|rivalry game]] played between the [[Virginia Cavaliers football]] team of the [[University of Virginia]] and the [[Virginia Tech Hokies football]] team of [[Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University]]. Typically, this series is played on a Saturday close to [[Thanksgiving]]. The trophy is an important component of the greater [[Virginia-Virginia Tech rivalry]]. Though the two schools first met in 1895 and have played annually since 1970, the Cup is a relatively new tradition, beginning in 1996. Currently, Virginia Tech holds the cup, having won the 2011 matchup by the score of 38-0. The Hokies have won eight consecutive games in the series. The Commonwealth Cup trophy itself is four feet high and contains the scores of all of the games in the Virginia-Virginia Tech series.[http://www.hokiesports.com/football/trophy/commonwealth.html hokiesports.com] Since the 1964 matchup, the game has always been played at either [[Lane Stadium]] or [[Scott Stadium]] on the campuses of the two universities. But the series has at times been played in [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] (1903, 1904, and 1957); [[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]] (1940, 1941, and 1942); and [[Roanoke, Virginia|Roanoke]] (in 17 of the 19 years between 1945 and 1963). Virginia Tech leads the all-time series between the schools 51-37-5,{{cite web|url=http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/acc/virginia_tech/opponents_records.php?teamid=3385|title=Virginia Tech vs Virginia|publisher=College Football Data Warehouse|accessdate=2009-06-29}} and the Cup series 11-3. At 93 games it is the longest series for the Hokies and the second-longest for the Cavaliers, after the 116-game series between Virginia and [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina]] known as the [[South's Oldest Rivalry]]. == Trophy == The trophy awarded to the winner of the Commonwealth Cup game is also referred to as the Commonwealth Cup, and was created in 1996. Constructed of [[marble]] and [[cherry]] wood, the Cup stands four feet tall and is capped by a silver-plated cup. The cup is engraved with the names of the two schools and is mounted atop a trapezoidal base that makes up most of the trophy's length. The results of every Virginia-Virginia Tech football game are engraved on the sides of the base, and the front of the base features a stylized map of Virginia with [[Blacksburg, Virginia|Blacksburg]] and [[Charlottesville, Virginia|Charlottesville]] represented by stars on the map.[http://www.hokiesports.com/football/trophy/commonwealth.html Hokiesports.com Commonwealth Cup Trophy]. Retrieved October 12, 2007. ==Game results== [[File:VirginiaTech-LaneStadium-VTvsUVA-2004-entrance.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The [[Virginia Tech]] cheerleaders welcome the [[University of Virginia|Virginia]] football team to [[Lane Stadium]] as the teams prepare for the 2004 battle for the Commonwealth Cup]] [[File:2006 UVA at VT postgame.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The [[University of Virginia|Virginia]] and [[Virginia Tech]] teams meet after the 2006 battle for the Commonwealth Cup.]] ''Virginia victories shaded in ââ navy blue. Virginia Tech victories are shaded ââ maroon. Ties are shaded ââ gray. background:maroon; color:#e65b00;" |93 || November 26, 2011 || Charlottesville, VA ||'''Virginia Tech''' || '''38''' ||Virginia || 0 || VT 51-37-5 |} ==Significant games== {{Refimprove|date=January 2011}} The 1998 game between the Cavaliers of Virginia and the Hokies of Virginia Tech was one of the biggest games in the series. UVa was down 29-7 and came back to win the game 36 to 32 by a touchdown pass from [[Aaron Brooks (American football)|Aaron Brooks]] to [[Ahmad Hawkins]]. It is still the biggest comeback in UVa history. In 2004, the battle for the Commonwealth Cup took on a new significance as the two teams were now both members of the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]]. Not only did the game count for bragging rights within the state, but it also would have an effect on the ACC title. Both teams entered the 2004 match-up able to clinch a share of the ACC championship with a win. Ultimately, Virginia Tech would prevail and go on to win the ACC outright in their first year in the conference. In 2007 the game took place Charlottesville and became the ''de facto'' Coastal Division championship game, the winner would then go and play in the ACC Championship Game. Both teams came in ranked nationally, Virginia Tech at #8 and Virginia at #16. Ultimately, Virginia Tech prevailed 33-21 and would go on to beat [[2007 Boston College Eagles football team|Boston College]], ACC Atlantic Division Champions, for the [[2007 ACC Championship Game|ACC Championship]]. Similar to 2007, the 2011 game was also the ''de facto'' Coastal Division title game. Both teams once again came in ranked nationally, Virginia Tech at #6 and Virginia at #24. A strong second half rushing performance by Virginia Tech halfback [[David Wilson (American football)|David Wilson]] guided the Hokies to a 38 point shutout of their arch rivals and a spot in the [[2011 ACC Championship Game]] against the [[2011 Clemson Tigers football team|Clemson Tigers]].http://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/virginia-tech-football-pounds-rival-virginia-38-0-earns-berth-in-acc-title-game/2011/11/26/gIQA7jbozN_story.html == See also == * [[Virginia-Virginia Tech rivalry]], the all-sports rivalry between the Cavaliers and Hokies. * [[South's Oldest Rivalry]], the longest-standing football rivalry in the ACC, between the Cavaliers and [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina]]. * [[Maryland-Virginia rivalry]], the official "permanent rivalry" in football between the Cavaliers and [[Maryland Terrapins football|Maryland]]. * [[Black Diamond Trophy]], the discontinued football rivalry trophy between the Hokies and [[West Virginia Mountaineers football|West Virginia]]. * [[List of NCAA college football rivalry games]] == References == == External links == * [http://www.hokiesports.com/football/ Official VT Athletics Site] * [http://virginiasports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/va-m-footbl-body.html Official UVA Athletics Site] {{Virginia Cavaliers football navbox}} {{Virginia Tech Hokies football navbox}} {{ACC rivalries}} [[Category:Atlantic Coast Conference]] [[Category:College football rivalry trophies in the United States]] [[Category:Virginia Cavaliers football]] [[Category:Virginia Tech Hokies football]] [[Category:College sports in Virginia]] [[ja:ã³ã¢ã³ã¦ã§ã«ã¹ã»ã«ãã]]
